Johns Hopkins News-Letter

College Literature

The News-Letter, as you know, is edited and published bY
the students; it gives the University news, and it gives all of it.
During the last few years in which the University has been
steadily growing it has been very loyally supported by the student body. We have reached the time now, where the Board
feels it is desirable to issue the NEWS-LETTER each Tuesday
and Friday during the collegiate year. And so, for the first time, it
is being done this year, at a cost of about $4,800.
Appearing twice a week will enable the editors to give advance notice of all games, meetings, lectures and other interesting gatherings, as well as an immediate and complete account
for the benefit of those unable to attend. We know you are interested in Hopkins' activities, in the progress of the dorms, in
the football team, lacrosse team, debating team, Dramatic Club,
etc. Perhaps you were a member of one of our championship
lacrosse teams—at any rate, you cherish fond memories of your
college days, and you have an interest in the activities of today
at Homewood; for that reason we have taken the liberty of
placing you on our subscription list, and your name will continue
there unless you send in the coupon below.
Subscription price is $2.50 per year, payable on or before
January 1, 1922. Won't you back us up and help make the new
semi-weekly a tremendous success?
G. P. Fallon,
Circulation Manager,
Homewood.

goal to win and immediately started
after it. Markell, who substituted
for Spinney when he was injured,
started the line plunging and had
carried the ball to Virginia's 35yard line before Virginia gaine'l
the ball on a pass, caught by Burge.
Hopkins had lost her last chance
and the remaining short time
availed nothing.
After the game, "Bill" Totterdale
was elected captain in place of
"Bill" Wood, who is now at West
Point. Totterdale has been acting
captain this season and his choice is
a popular one.

Johns Hopkins News-Letter

College Literature

The News-Letter, as you know, is edited and published bY
the students; it gives the University news, and it gives all of it.
During the last few years in which the University has been
steadily growing it has been very loyally supported by the student body. We have reached the time now, where the Board
feels it is desirable to issue the NEWS-LETTER each Tuesday
and Friday during the collegiate year. And so, for the first time, it
is being done this year, at a cost of about $4,800.
Appearing twice a week will enable the editors to give advance notice of all games, meetings, lectures and other interesting gatherings, as well as an immediate and complete account
for the benefit of those unable to attend. We know you are interested in Hopkins' activities, in the progress of the dorms, in
the football team, lacrosse team, debating team, Dramatic Club,
etc. Perhaps you were a member of one of our championship
lacrosse teams—at any rate, you cherish fond memories of your
college days, and you have an interest in the activities of today
at Homewood; for that reason we have taken the liberty of
placing you on our subscription list, and your name will continue
there unless you send in the coupon below.
Subscription price is $2.50 per year, payable on or before
January 1, 1922. Won't you back us up and help make the new
semi-weekly a tremendous success?
G. P. Fallon,
Circulation Manager,
Homewood.

Of the Better Class

on Hopkins' 18-yard line. Dunn
and Oppleman worked the ball to
the two-yard line. Foster carried
the ball over for a second touchdown and Hall made his first failure of the season at goal kicking.
Hopkins needed a touchdown and
goal to win and immediately started
after it. Markell, who substituted
for Spinney when he was injured,
started the line plunging and had
carried the ball to Virginia's 35yard line before Virginia gaine'l
the ball on a pass, caught by Burge.
Hopkins had lost her last chance
and the remaining short time
availed nothing.
After the game, "Bill" Totterdale
was elected captain in place of
"Bill" Wood, who is now at West
Point. Totterdale has been acting
captain this season and his choice is
a popular one.
